discussion.author: shinnar
discussion.comment:
Hi!  What version of Coq are you using?  We currently use `8.12.2`.  Something in the `8.12` line should work, but we have not tested with newer versions, and it is very likely that things break due to changes in hypothesis naming and such.

If this is a problem for your intended use case (e.g. if you are thinking of using it as part of another development), please tell us, and what version of Coq you need to use.

discussion.author: davidenitti
discussion.comment: thanks, I managed to compile it by downgrading coq, do you know how I can import the library in coqide? (I'm new with coq)

discussion.author: shinnar
discussion.comment: Inspired by your post, I just updated our repo to support coq 8.16.1 (it should still support 8.12.2 as well, so no need to change back)

discussion.author: shinnar
discussion.comment: If you use opam, running something like `opam install .` in the FormalML directory should work

discussion.author: davidenitti
discussion.comment:
thank you very much, with the new updated version of the code when I import FormalML.ProbTheory.Event I have this error:
`
Compiled library FormalML.ProbTheory.Event (in file /home/davide/code/coq/FormalML/coq/ProbTheory/Event.vo) makes inconsistent assumptions over library Coq.Init.Ltac
`
do you know how to fix this?
I'm doing coqide -R /home/davide/code/coq/FormalML/coq/ FormalML
because even installing with opam install . I can't find it without specifying the library
(with the old code and old version of coqide 8.12.2 it was working)

discussion.author: shinnar
discussion.comment: try `make clean`and then either `make` or `opam install .`  btw, you can run `make -j 4` or something similar to compile some files in parallel, if your machine has multiple cores and enough memory

discussion.author: kodyvajjha
discussion.comment: @davidenitti if you are using proof general + emacs, there is a flag `coq-compile-before-require-toggle` which you can set to recompile all the files that you import using `Require`. Within CoqIde there is also a `Compile > Make` option that I see which might help, although I haven't tried it myself.

discussion.author: davidenitti
discussion.comment:
thanks it works now, but I still have to specify the library in the call: coqide -R FormalML/coq FormalML, not sure if there is a way to automatically find the library. (I installed with opam install with the new code).
if also there is any paper that explain the library would be great.
thank you very much for the support!

discussion.author: shinnar
discussion.comment: I would recommend putting that in a `_CoqProject` file (which lives in your top level directory): you can create such a file with `-R FormalML/coq FormalML` as the only line in it.  CoqIDE, as well as other coq tools should read that file and add the argument for you

discussion.author: shinnar
discussion.comment: Section 3 of https://arxiv.org/pdf/2202.05959.pdf gives highlights of some of the development, although we have added more since then (also, it is of course simplified).
